abstract.p: Michael Porter reviews book Night of Amber by Sylvie Germain (S)

block.p: In her previous novel, ''The Book of Nights,'' Sylvie Germain followed the Peniels, a long-suffering peasant family, on their journey from an ancestral river barge to a farm in Flanders. Through three wars, they endured more than their share of misfortune as maimings, disfigurements and grotesque deaths piled up into an enormous mountain of woe. In this sequel, fortune wastes no time in striking the Peniels yet again; ''Night of Amber'' begins with a child's death in a hunting accident. That child's brother, Charles-Victor, grows up hard and spiteful, resenting his mother's inconsolable grief and his father's inattention. ''Night of Amber'' is primarily Charles-Victor's story, recounting his emotional wounding, the wounds he inflicts and the unexpected healing that not only redeems him but also brings a kind of resolution to the family's troubles. Historical events like the Algerian war and the 1968 Paris demonstrations once again anchor the story, and the strange magic that has afflicted the family continues. Germain's writing is frequently artful in Christine Donougher's translation; too often, however, the author drowns this story in language that is breathless and overheated.
